title: Defining Input and Output
text: The first step is to identify the changing variables and assigning them to input and output. Our input will be $$t$$, time in hours, and our output will be A(t), distance in miles, and E(t), distance in miles.

title: Drawing a Diagram
text: Because it is not obvious how to define our output variable, we’ll start by drawing a picture such as in the image attached to this hint.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Identifying the Initial Value
text: They both start at the same intersection so when $$t=0$$, the distance traveled by each person should also be $$0$$. Thus the initial value for each is $$0$$.

title: Identifying the Rate of Change
text: Anna is walking $$4$$ miles per hour and Emanuel is walking $$3$$ miles per hour, which are both rates of change. The slope for A is $$4$$ and the slope for E is $$3$$.

title: Defining a Coordinate System
text: For this problem, the distances from the starting point are important. To notate these, we can define a coordinate system, identifying the “starting point” at the intersection where they both started. Then we can use the variable, A, which we introduced above, to represent Anna’s position, and define it to be a measurement from the starting point in the eastward direction. Likewise, can use the variable, E, to represent Emanuel’s position, measured from the starting point in the southward direction. Note that in defining the coordinate system, we specified both the starting point of the measurement and the direction of measure.

title: Defining a Third Variable, D
text: We can then define a third variable, D, to be the measurement of the distance between Anna and Emanuel. Showing the variables on the diagram is often helpful, as we can see from the attached image. Recall that we need to know how long it takes for D, the distance between them, to equal $$2$$ miles. Notice that for any given input 𝑡, the outputs A(t), E(t), and D(t) represent distances.\n##figure2.gif##

title: Solving D(t) as a Linear Function
text: $$D(t)=5t;$$ this means that the distance between Anna and Emanuel is also a linear function. Because D is a linear function, we can now answer the question of when the distance between them will reach $$2$$ miles. We will set the output $$D(t)=2D(t)=2$$ and solve for $$t$$.
